abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column notes Emigrant Savings Bank head Howard P Milstein's arguments that expansion of bank's subprime loan program in early 2000s both saved bank and provided service to community, despite bank's charging 18 percent interest rate to homeowners who could ill afford it; Milstein has taken stand in federal trial against Emigrant in Brooklyn.

headline.print_headline: Saving a Bank by Charging 18% Interest
headline.main: A Benefactor, His Home Loans, and Pain

snippet: Howard P. Milstein runs Emigrant Savings Bank, which is accused of illegal lending practices that were marketed to minority homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Howard P. Milstein runs Emigrant Savings Bank, which is accused of illegal lending practices that were marketed to minority homeowners.
